transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: I'm Robert Siegel at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland. It is day three. Donald Trump and Mike Pence have been nominated. Pence speaks tonight to a convention that's trying to unify around the ticket. But there are still people on the floor who have their doubts. Meet one of them.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: My name's Artemio Muniz. Everybody calls me Temo. I am chairman of the Federation of Hispanic Republicans. It's an auxiliary of the Republican Party of Texas. And I'm also an alternate delegate from Texas.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: Artemio Muniz is 35. He's a freshly minted lawyer from Houston who has run a state legislative campaign and who quotes conservative intellectuals like economists Milton Friedman and Friedrich von Hayek. When it comes to Donald Trump, he's not there yet.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: I'm a blank - leave-it-blank delegate.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: Leave-it-blank delegate. You're an uncommitted...

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: ...Delegate.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: But I will - if Trump makes the necessary changes for immigration, his talking points and Hispanic (unintelligible), I would consider helping him on his campaign.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: Boy, he doesn't seem likely to make a big change about immigration. And the Platform Committee, they wanted the dimensions of the fence to be written in at one point.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: I think the wall is not the big issue. I think it's what are you going to do with the 11 million people who are here illegally? Mass deportations are a concern. We don't want mass deportations. If he can change to a legalization program which allows people to apply here in the United States at a consulate and not in a foreign government where there's a lot of corruption, I'm willing to go with him with it.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: So even when he says they have to go back first and then they can come home, that wouldn't be satisfactory.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: That's a nonstarter for me because...

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: Nonstarter for you.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: ...Well, you're going to break up the families. You're going to have people losing their jobs, rental agreements. Worst off, you're going to have other governments deciding whether they can come back or not.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: Your parents were illegal immigrants to the United States.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: They were, from San Luis Potosi, Mexico. My dad was a shepherd boy, lived in the mountains, no electricity, no water. And he came here at the age of 14.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: And the reason that he and your mother became citizens was...

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Ronald Reagan.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: ...The Reagan SimpsonâMazzoli Act...

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: ...That led to the amnesty that is much attacked in these political quarters quite often.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: That's right, and it's a mistake because you had 3 million individuals from Mexico and Central America who received a gift. And those people have gone on to have kids like me. And a lot of those kids I know, they're serving in the military, they're business owners, they're successful and they vote. And whenever you attack immigrants and talk about amnesty, you're talking about them as well. And we're leaving a huge constituency behind simply because of cheap primary politics.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: Well, do you have this conversation with people when you're...

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Absolutely.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: ...In Texas? Do you hear them saying why are the Republicans - why do they sound so anti-immigrant when Reagan himself did the amnesty?

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Well, one thing is I think the Reagan legacy has sort of been tarnished where a lot of people in the conservative echo chamber will only pick and choose what Reagan said. But you also have W. Bush, George W. Bush, who also pushed for immigration reform. And I remember his outreach videos. He would actually stand in parades waving Mexican flags. I can only imagine what would happen if Trump waved the Mexican flag nowadays.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: If you'd written a paper in law school...

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: ...That draws directly on somebody else's paper, as Melania's speech drew upon Michelle Obama's speech...

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Oh, that's a tough one.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: ...Would you get called out by a professor for that?

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Oh, absolutely. I wouldn't be here right now. I'd be picking fruit or something. But, no, the deal is, you know, I don't think it's plagiarizing. I see it as more as, like, rappers and comedians, you're kind of borrowing from somebody else.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: It seems like sampling. Like...

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Yeah, sampling, there you go.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: ...We convert some surface scratch thrown in when we came to those words.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Yeah, sampling loops and beats. You know, and there's no court to try you for using another politician's words.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: Well, just, you know, before you go, I mean, you mentioned you need to hear something on immigration...

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: ...To bring you around 'cause you're not yet a Trump voter.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: I'm not, no. At this point, I'm not.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: How hopeful are you that you're actually going to hear a proposal that you can live with?

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: I am hopeful because the campaign has reached out to me. And I know a lot of my friends who are in the campaign who are of like mindset and they are really working towards convincing Donald Trump. And I think, look, he's a businessman. I think he wants to win. I want to win. It's sort of like he's negotiating sort of.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: You think he's going to say, OK, here's a plan for 11 million immigrants here illegally. They can go to a consulate in this country, get some papers and apply? You think he can get that through a convention like this and a party like this?

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: I don't think it would be at the convention. I think it'll be later on down the road when he has a chance to really look at things and see if he really wants to go down that road. Now, it's going to be tough because some people in the base will scream amnesty at any solution. But Trump's gifted. If you notice, he can take a position one second, then the other. But he really sells it. And if he believes it, I think that that leadership quality in him will really convince the base.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: Artemio Muniz, alternate delegate from Texas - uncommitted and undecided...

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: Robert Siegel
transcript.text: ...Alternate delegate from Texas. Thanks so much for talking with us.

transcript.speaker: Artemio Muniz
transcript.text: Thank you. Thank you very much.
